creditline: Gift of Elizabeth, Julie, and Catherine Andrus in memory of John and Marion Andrus
inscription:
Signature, Date, Inscription, Stamp

inscribed in plate at top: [NESSI VESTE RABIDVS SE COMBVRIT HERCVLES / PHILOCRASSES]
markings: brown stamp on verso, LL: Victor Honig, Lugt 4820
provenance: Victor Honig (1921-2013), Lugt 4820, San Francisco. [David Tunick, New York; sold to Andrus]; John E. Andrus III, Wayzata, Minn.; by descent to his daughters, Elizabeth, Katie, and Julie; gave to MIA, 2015. Earlier provenances have been gathered, but further research will increase our knowledge of their histories.
signed: monogram and date in plate at lower right: [1548 / HSB]
text:
The legendary strongman Hercules was born to the god Zeus and a mortal named Alcmena. This union so incensed Zeus’s wife Hera that she made life almost unbearable for the hero. Her ire resulted in him undertaking a series of tasks, known as the Twelve Labors of Hercules. Sebald Beham challenged his audience’s knowledge of the classical text, engraving three actual labors and nine scenes of Hercules’ exploits before and after his labors.

Tortured by the poisoned robe, Hercules asks the shepherd Philoctetes to light the pyre so he can end his misery. In return, Philoctetes receives his weapons.
title: Death of Hercules, From the Labors of Hercules
